availability.p: Copyright © 2018, Christopher Alan Mosher, Shelton, Connecticut, USA.
availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

TO PHYSICIANS
1 The attendiuK phyifcian must furnish a wrtificate to the Departmrat of Heakh ̂ Wn Mh» Item ".'rr'"'" '
must be furnished by him forthwith (Sanitary Code, Sections 33 and 90).
2 AU physicians practicing in The City of New York (including those m public institutions)must be registered in the Bureau of Records (Sanitary Code, Section 218).
3 If a person dies from criminal violence or by a casualty w by suldde, or
while In appSSt health, or when unattended by a phyaldan or In prison, or m smy smjiU^
or manner, it shall be the duty of any citizen who nuybeOTnc aware of
mich person to report such death forthwith to the office of the chief m^ical ezammer, ̂ to a
officer who shaU forthwith notify the officer in charge of the sUtion how u^e
such person died. Any person who shall wilfully neglect or refuse to report such d«^ w wto
without written order from a medical examiner shall wilfully touch, remove or oisturo rhe bo-ay ̂
ly such person, or \rilfuUy touch, remove, or disturb the clothing, or anySrS^^^tyofaLdem;anor. (Inserted by Laws 191S, Chapter 284, Sectmn 2. In effect
[anuary 1,1918.) , , / i,
4. Certificates wUl be returned for additional Information which give any of the foUowmg
without explanation, as the sole cause of death:
Abortion, Hemorrhaffe, Meningitis, PhleWds,
v\\ Cellulltls, Gimjrene, Metritls, l^acmla,
^ Childbirth, Gastritis, Miscarriage, ^tlcaemla,
\^Convul8lon8, Eryiripelas, Peritonitis, Tetanus.
(Any one of these may be the result of an injury, and thus be a mbject for mvestigatioo by a
Medical Examiner. If it is not, the certificate should make that fact plain.)
5. No certificate giving "Heart failure," "Dropsy," or other inere symptom as the sole
cause of death will be accepted, unless accompanied by a satisfactory wntten exi^anation.
6. Statement of Occupation.—Precise statement of occupation is vwy importan^ so ̂ t the
relative healthfulness of various pursuiu can be known. The question applim to mch ̂ ev^
person, irrespective of age. For many occupations a single word or term on t^ ̂ line be
e. g.. Former or PlanUr, Physician, Compositor, Architect, Locomotuo Engineer, Ctod Enpnecr,
Stationary Fireman, etc. But in many cases, especially in industrial emjdoyments, it is necessary
to know (a) the kind of work and also ffi) the nature of the buslneae or industry, ̂ therefore^
additional line is provided for the latter statement it should be used only when nwdeiL Asexamplcss-
fo) Spinner, (b) Cotton MiU; (a) Salesman, (b) Grocery; (a) Foreman, (b) AntomofnU FaOory.
TO UNDERTAKERS
fj.
1. No burial permit can be obtained without a proper certificate.
2. Certificates must be written throughout in black ink.
3. No certificate will be accepted which is mutilated. Illegible, Inaccurate,^ or uy porti^
of which has been erased. Interlined, corrected or altered, as all sudi changes impair its value
as a public record.
